pchem_nodes.text: Welcome to a choose-your-own-adventure game made by Carl, where you get to have fun (hopefully) and also learn some chemistry along the way (also hopefully)! -- For a tutorial or information on formatting your answers, type 'help'. If this is your first time, check out the tutorial before moving on. -- You can find the GitHub repository for this app at https://github.com/OrigamiKoala/chem-text-adventure -- It would be greatly appreciated if you could take a minute to fill out a super short feedback form. Thank you so much! -- Type anything to start from the beginning.

And that is where the story ends...for now. Check back in a couple days and there might be something new :) -- Check out GitHub repository for this app at https://github.com/OrigamiKoala/chem-text-adventure -- All of the activities can be found here -- Interested in chemistry? Check out:
  • Cartoon Guide to Chemistry
  • Khan Academy's Chemistry courses
  • Chemistry by Steven S. Zumdahl
  • Chemical Principles by Steven S. Zumdahl
  • Atkins' Chemical Principles by Peter Atkins
  • Atkins' Physical Chemistry by Peter Atkins
  • Inorganic Chemistry by Gary L. Miessler
  • Organic Chemistry by David Klein
  • Organic Chemistry by Jonathan Clayden
-- It would be greatly appreciated if you could take a minute to fill out a super short feedback form. Thank you so much!
Sorry, that section does not exist yet.

Section 1: Atoms and Molecules

--

History of the Atom

-- A long long time ago, some ancient Greek dudes asked a very interesting question: Could you keep on slicing something into smaller pieces forever? -- Well, let's do an activity to find out. -- Atomos Activity -- Click on the activity, and make a copy of the document. Try the activity. Then, answer the questions, and come back here. -- Type anything once you are done.

Do you think you can keep slicing something in half forever? --
  1. Yes, definitely!
  2. Uhh....no

Some Greeks thought the answer was "yes", but one guy, Democritus, agreed with you. He decided at some point, you would reach the smallest thing in the universe that couldn't be split further. He called this atomos, meaning "indivisible". Later, scientists would call these super small particles "atoms". -- But these were ancient Greeks, and they didn't yet have the tools to do fancy experiments to figure out the truth. So they kind of just forgot about atoms and agreed that all of matter was made of four elements: earth, air, fire, and water (hence Avatar). What's your favorite element? --
  1. Earth
  2. Air
  3. Fire
  4. Water

Nice choice :) -- Well, skip a couple centuries and along come the alchemists! These were people who believed in the idea of four elements. Three of their most famous goals were to make a panacea (something that could cure all diseases), find or make an elixir of immortality (that could ensure they lived forever), and turn any metal into gold (for more info see here). Basically, you know, your typical life goals. -- History kind of portrayed alchemists as superstitious crackpots who had no idea what they were doing, and were super greedy. -- I don't know how accurate that is, given that Isaac Newton (the guy who introduced the idea of gravity) was also an alchemist... -- But the alchemists did something very important... they wrote down what they did! -- In fact, they wrote down a lot of data and observations that they collected from their experiments, and these notebooks would later be pretty useful for later chemists. Do you write stuff down?
  1. Absolutely!
  2. Nope

A lot of Greeks agreed with you.
--
Wow! Look at that! You made a hypothesis, which is basically an answer to a question you are asking. Science revolves around making hypotheses, and then using experiments to back your ideas up (or prove them wrong)
--
Well, how many pieces did you end up with?

That's a lot of pieces! I certainly didn't end up with that many pieces when I tried!
--
Well, it looks like our idea that things could be divided forever wasn't exactly true...but that's okay! Science is filled with wrong ideas, and today scientists still aren't really sure if all their ideas are right.
--
Why do you think you couldn't keep on going after a certain point?

Good idea. Well, now what do you think? Can you forever divide something into smaller pieces?
  1. Definitely
  2. Nope
Well, good job! You have great habits! Just curious: what app do you use?

Hmmm...that's okay. I would suggest writing stuff down though - it could come useful in the future. Also, it builds good habits for a scientist. 
--
Type anything to continue.

Nice app! I might give it a try.
--
Type anything to continue.

Well anyway, mankind kind of forgot about atoms until the 18th century, when a lot of questions about matter surfaced. One of the important guys was John Dalton, who decided Democritus was probably right about atomos. He called these tiny particles "atoms". -- As it turns out, however, atoms are not actually indivisible - there are smaller particles. For the smallest particles known to mankind, search up "standard model of particle physics". Domain of Science has a great YouTube video on this. TED-ED does too! -- Type anything to continue

Atomic Structure

-- You know about magnets, right? They have a North pole and a South pole. One of them is positively charged, and the other is negatively charged. Do you know which one is which? (It's okay if you don't; I didn't either until I searched it up) --
  1. North is positive, South is negative
  2. South is positive, North is negative
  3. I don't know

Nice job! I didn't know this, but apparently the north pole is generally considered the positive end? Which is funny, because Earth's "North Pole" (the one with Santa) is actually negative...and Earth actually has two North Poles...and the North and South Pole flip every couple thousand years...(see here) -- The real world is so confusing. -- Type anything to continue.

You're actually half right. Turns out the Earth's "South Pole" is positive. But it's generally accepted that for most magnets, the north pole is the positive end, and the south pole is the negative end. See more about the Earth's wacky four different poles here). -- But hey, I didn't know the North was positive either, at least until I searched it up. -- Type anything to continue.

That's ok! I didn't know either until I searched it up. It's good that you aren't randomly guessing - for this game, guessing is fine, but in real world science, try not to guess too much :) -- Turns out the north pole of a magnet is the positive end, and the south pole is the negative end. But for this planet we live on, it's actually the opposite - our "North Pole" (the one with Santa) is negative...but the poles switch every couple thousand years... (see here). -- Not at all confusing... -- Type anything to continue

The positive end of one magnet attracts the negative end of another magnet. I know that's confusing, but hey, I didn't make up the laws of physics :)
--
As a result of the positive ends and negative ends being attracted, the positive end snaps to the negative end if you bring them close enough. If you want, now is the time to grab some magnets and try this out. This is also oddly satisfying.
--
Type anything to continue.

Enough about magnets. -- Atoms are kind of like tiny magnets - they have positive parts, and negative parts. The positive parts are called protons, and the negative parts are called electrons. You can imagine them as tiny little specks or balls (particles). -- The protons are all bundled together in the center, called the nucleus, and the electrons orbit around the nucleus. -- For magnets, pushing two ends with the same charge (positive or negative) is extremely difficult, and requires lots of energy. So do you think the nucleus contains a lot of energy? --
  1. Yep
  2. Nope

That's right! Since the nucleus contains a whole bunch of positive particles, a lot of energy must be used to keep the nucleus together.
--
If you've ever heard of nuclear bombs or nuclear energy, they are essentially processes that split the nuclei (plural of nucleus) of atoms. That means the protons are separated.
--
Nuclear bombs and nuclear power plants release a lot of energy. Why do you think this is the case?
Why do you think the nucleus is low energy?

Well, even though an atom is pretty stable, the nucleus is actually super high energy, since the protons are packed so close together.
--
In order for the protons (which are all positive) to be so close, there must be a lot of energy used to hold the nucleus together, so the nucleus is pretty high in energy.
--
If you've ever heard of nuclear bombs or nuclear energy, they are essentially processes that split the nuclei (plural of nucleus) of atoms. That means the protons are separated.
--
Nuclear bombs and nuclear power plants release a lot of energy. Why do you think this is the case?

They release energy because the nuclei split, so protons of the atoms aren't so tightly packed into the nuclei anymore. All the energy that once held the nucleus together is no longer needed, so it is released in one big BOOM! -- That's a pretty simplified version. For a more complicated version, check out the nuclear chemistry section, or google "nuclear physics". The Institute for Energy and Environmental Research has a good article introducing nuclear physics, which is a whole field of science in itself. -- Type anything to continue.

There is also a third particle in the atom - the neutron, which has no charge. It isn't positive or negative, and it's found in the nucleus.
--
Type anything to continue.

All atoms are made of protons, neutrons, and electrons - but with different amounts. -- The number of protons in an atom's nucleus determines its "element". Atoms are kind of like Legos - they come in different types. -- The number of protons and electrons determines how an atom behaves. Atoms with different numbers of protons and electrons behave differently, kind of like how Legos with different shapes fit together differently and are used for different things. -- We have a table of all the different elements - called the "Periodic Table of the Elements" or just the "Periodic Table".
-- The number on top of each element symbol is the number of protons in an atom of that element. -- Different periodic tables have slightly different numbers underneath the elements. From now on, we will use the periodic table above. If you need to summon it at any point, type 'periodic table'. The periodic table we will use comes from https://ptable.com, which has a dynamic periodic table full of useful information. -- Fun fact: there is also a periodic table of legos:
-- So, looking at the periodic table, how many protons does an oxygen atom have?
pchem_nodes.hint: Find oxygen on the periodic table.

pchem_nodes.text:
Nice job!
--
Now, on to the electrons.
--
The electrons are super tiny particles that weigh basically nothing, and have a negative charge. They kind of orbit the nucleus of an atom. Why do you think they orbit, instead of flying away?

It's because the nucleus is positively charged (since it has a ton of protons), and this attracts the electrons, which are negatively charged. -- So the electrons orbit around the nucleus - but they do so at different distances. -- Time for another activity!

Model of an Atom -- Complete the activity and then come back here. -- Type anything to continue.

Knowing that it requires energy to pull a positively and negatively charged thing apart, which electrons do you think have the highest energy, the 'farthest' ones, the 'middle' ones, or the 'closest' ones?
pchem_nodes.hint: Your options are 'farthest', 'middle', or 'closest'.

pchem_nodes.text:
Yep! The farthest electrons have the highest energy, because it requires a lot of energy to stay far away from the positive nucleus. -- The electrons in an atom have different energies based on how far away they are from the nucleus. These levels of energies are called shells. The shell farthest from the atom is called the valence shell, and the highest energy (farthest away) electrons are called valence electrons. -- Nature (and an atom) wants to be lazy (just like mathematicians...and scientists... and humans in general...) - which means they want to have the lowest amount of energy possible. In fact, nature will try pretty hard to do this - and we will see why in the later section on thermodynamics. -- So which kind of shell do you think atoms want to fill first, as they gain electrons? --
  1. The highest energy ones
  2. The middle ones
  3. The lowest energy ones
If an atom doesn't have many electrons, the nucleus is super positive and unbalanced, and it pulls super hard on the electrons the atom does have. Can these electrons stay super far away?

Yep! The electrons can't stay far away - so they end up closer.
--
As an atom adds electrons, the nucleus becomes less and less unbalanced, and pulls less hard on these new electrons. So are they closer or farther away?

So which kind of shell do you think atoms want to fill first, as they gain electrons? --
  1. The highest energy ones
  2. The middle ones
  3. The lowest energy ones

That's a great hypothesis!
--
But, in order to stay in the medium shells, an electron must feel a medium pull from the nucleus - not too strong, not too weak. However, when there are only a few electrons, the nucleus pulls super hard on the electrons.
--
So can the electrons stay in the medium shells for very long?

Nice!
--
Another way to think about this is when an atom doesn't have many electrons, the nucleus is super positive, and it wants any new electrons to be as close as possible. But as an atom gains electrons, the new electrons feel the nucleus's pull less and less...and so end up farther away.
--
Type anything to continue.

Electronegativity

-- As it turns out, atoms are lowest in energy when they have full shells. -- Since atoms want to have the lowest energy possible, they are happiest when they have full shells. -- So if atom A is one electron short of a full shell, and atom B is two electrons short of a full shell, which one do you think is more desparate for electrons? Type 'A' or 'B'.
pchem_nodes.hint: Atom A is so close... but atom B is farther away from reaching a full shell.

pchem_nodes.text: Since A is the closest to being happy, it will be the most desparate for electrons, and thus pull on electrons more. This pull is called electronegativity. Atoms closest to full shells have the highest electronegativities. -- On the periodic table, each column of atoms (for the most part) has the same number of valence electrons in its neutral state, and when you go across a row, the number of valence electrons increases. For example, lithium in its neutral state has 1 valence electron. Beryllium has 2 valence electrons. Boron has 3, carbon has 4, nitrogen has 5, oxygen has 6, and so on so forth. -- In most periodic tables, above each column, you will see a little number between 1 and 18. This is the group number of the column. Each column is called a group. -- Here's a little shortcut to finding the number of valence electrons in an atom - just look at the last digit of the group number! (This only works for groups 1, 2, and 13-18 - the ones on the sides of the table). -- So given the information above, how many valence electrons does sulfur have?
pchem_nodes.hint: Find sulfur on the periodic table.

pchem_nodes.text:
The column on the very right (starting with helium) are called "noble gases", because they have full valence shells. They are the happiest of the atoms! Remember, all atoms want to have full shells.
--
The column to the left of the noble gases are called "halogens". How many electrons short are they from a full shell?

So, do you think the halogens have a high electronegativity or a low electronegativity? --
  1. high
  2. low
Very good! Why?
Hmmm... remember that having a high electronegativity means that the atoms are really desparate for electrons - they want electrons very badly. Do halogens want electrons really badly?

Nice! -- If an atom has few electrons in its valence shell, it doesn't want electrons at all - in fact, it wants to get rid of electrons. Why do you think this is the case? See the image below, which shows an atom:

For an atom with only a few valence electrons, the easiest way for it to have a full outer shell is if it gets rid of all the electrons in its outer shell - and then the shell underneath is full!
--
So if lithium has one valence electron, does it want to 'lose it' or 'fill the valence shell'?
pchem_nodes.hint: Is it easier for lithium to lose 1 electron or gain 7?

pchem_nodes.text:
Very nice!
--
For atoms with a half-filled shell, it is difficult to either lose all the electrons or get enough electrons to fill the outer shell. We will see later on how these atoms manage to still be happy, though :)
--
Now, do you think that electronegativity 'increases' as you move across a row of the periodic table, or 'decreases'?
pchem_nodes.hint: As you move across a row, what happens to the number of electrons in the valence shell?

pchem_nodes.text:
That's right!
--
Type anything to continue.

Isotopes and Atomic Mass

-- Atoms with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons are called isotopes. They pretty much behave the same, but look different - like how different Legos with the same shape but different color behave the same, but look different. -- Type anything to continue.

Each type of atom weighs a slightly different amount. The weight of an atom is called its atomic mass, and is reported in atomic mass units (amu). We generally assume a proton has a mass of 1 amu, and a neutron also has a mass of 1 amu. However, electrons have so little mass we don't count it. -- We name isotopes based on their atomic mass. For example, carbon-13 has an atomic mass of 13 amu. -- So if an atom has 16 protons and 16 neutrons, what is its atomic mass?
pchem_nodes.hint: A proton has a mass of 1 amu, and a neutron has a mass of 1 amu.

pchem_nodes.text: Very good! -- Now, remember how I said that different isotopes have different numbers of neutrons? Well, since they have different numbers of neutrons, they have different masses - but they still are the same element! -- That becomes annoying. As chemists, we would really like to know what the mass of an iron atom is, but if iron shows up in multiple different isotopes, we can't give the mass of an iron atom an exact number that works 100% of the time! -- So we decided to just use the average atomic mass for our calculations. -- This average atomic mass doesn't have to be an integer - for example, the average atomic mass of nitrogen is 14.007 amu. But no nitrogen atom has an atomic mass of 14.007. However, on average, any given nitrogen atom has an atomic mass of 14.007. -- If you are still confused, imagine this. You got a 100, a 97, and a 91 on three tests. On average, you scored a 96 - but you didn't score a 96 on any test. -- Similarly, no nitrogen atom has an atomic mass of 14.007 amu, but on average, if you look at enough nitrogen atoms, the average atomic mass is 14.007 amu. -- Let's say carbon exists as primarily 2 isotopes: carbon-12 and carbon-13. Carbon-12's relative abundance is 98.9%, while carbon-13's relative abundance is 1.1%. This means that 98.9% of all carbon atoms are carbon-12, and 1.1% of all carbon atoms are carbon-13. -- To calculate the average atomic mass of carbon, let's look at 1000 random atoms. For every 1000 atoms, how many will be carbon-13?

Very good!
--
How many of the 1000 atoms will be carbon-12?

Nice!
--
So what is the total mass in amu of all the carbon-13 atoms?
pchem_nodes.hint: How many carbon-13 atoms are there? What is the mass of each?

pchem_nodes.text:
You're on a roll!
--
What's the total mass (in amu) of all the carbon-12 atoms? Do not express your answer in scientific notation.
pchem_nodes.hint: How many carbon-12 atoms are there? What is the mass of each?

pchem_nodes.text:
Wow! You did a lot of number crunching. We're almost there:
--
What is the total mass of all the 1000 carbon atoms? Do not express your answer in scientific notation.

Yep.
--
So what is the average mass of the carbon atoms?
pchem_nodes.hint: How much do the atoms weigh in total? How many atoms are there?

pchem_nodes.text:
Great job!
--
On a periodic table, the little number next to the element symbol that appears as a decimal is the average atomic mass of the element.
--
So, looking at any periodic table you want, what is the average atomic mass of hydrogen?
pchem_nodes.hint: Find hydrogen on the table.

pchem_nodes.text:
Alright!
--
Let's do a practice problem:
--
Suppose element X exists as three isotopes: X-110, X-111, and X-112. The relative abundance of X-110 is 56.40%. The relative abundance of X-111 is 23.90%. What is the average atomic mass of X?
pchem_nodes.hint: Look at what we did above. What percentage of atoms of element X will be X-112?

pchem_nodes.text:
Whew. That was a lot of math!
--
Type anything to continue.

Molecules

-- There are only 118 elements of the periodic table. Of these, only 92 naturally exist in the universe. Of these, only 90 exist on Earth. -- These 90 elements combine in lots of different ways to form molecules. You can imagine molecules as simple figures made from legos, which larger builds are made of. Atoms (legos) combine to form molecules, which then make up the world around us. -- We can describe any molecule by what atoms combine to form it. For example, you've probably heard that water is \(\ce{H_2O}\), which means one water molecule is made of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom combined together. -- This is called the molecular formula of the molecule. It is kind of like the ingredients list in a recipe. -- So how many carbon atoms are in one molecule of benzene \(\ce{C_6H_6}\)?
pchem_nodes.hint: The symbol for carbon is "C"

pchem_nodes.text:
Very good! -- Remember when we talked about electronegativity? -- An atom is most stable, with the least energy, when its valence shell is full. -- Well, let's say there are two atoms, A and B. A has one electron in its valence shell. Does he want to get rid of this electron? --
  1. Yes
  2. No
Why not?

Hmmmm...consider which is easier for A: lose its electron or get a bunch more electrons to fill the valence shell. -- So, does A want to get rid of his only valence electron? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

Yes! -- B is one electron short from a full valence shell. Does she want to get rid of her valence electrons? --
  1. Yep!
  2. Nope.

Hmmmm...consider which is easier for B: lose her electron or get a bunch more electrons to fill her valence shell. -- So, does B want to get rid of her valence electrons? --
  1. Yes
  2. No

You're right!
--
She desparately wants to get one more valence electron, so she will pull on any electron super hard.
--
Now, A doesn't want his valence electron, and is super happy to give it away.
--
What do you think will happen?

Yep!
--
Now, A just lost an electron. Is he 'positively charged' or 'negatively charged'?

Nice.
--
B just got an electron. Is she 'positively charged' or 'negatively charged'?

So if A is positively charged and B is negatively charged, what will happen? --
  1. Nothing
  2. They will be attracted
  3. They will be repelled
pchem_nodes.hint: Remember that atoms are basically tiny magnets, and opposites attract...

pchem_nodes.text: That's right! -- A and B will in fact be so attracted that they form a bond, called an ionic bond. -- Molecules are held together by bonds like these. -- Will carbon and oxygen form an ionic bond? Type 'yes' or 'no'.
pchem_nodes.hint: Find carbon and oxygen on the periodic table. Is one of them willing to give away an electron, and is one of them desparate for an electron?

pchem_nodes.text:
You're learning really fast!
--
So that poses a problem. So far, we haven't seen a way for carbon and oxygen to bond, since neither of them is willing to give away electrons.
--
But carbon dioxide is a molecule made of carbon bonded to two oxygens. So what happened?
--
Well, as it turns out, if neither atom pulls on the electrons much more than the other, the two atoms end up sharing.
--
Then, both atoms can have a full shell - kinda. It's glitching the system, pretty much - both atoms consider the electrons to be their own, so both can get a full shell, so both are happy!
--
In this case, do carbon and oxygen form a covalent bond? Type 'yes' or 'no'.

Nice job! -- Since neither oxygen nor carbon is willing to give up an electron, they end up sharing some of their electrons. -- In the case of carbon dioxide, the oxygen on the left shares two of its electrons with the carbon. The carbon also shares two of its own electrons, so in total, the carbon and oxygen share four electrons. -- Thus, the oxygen and carbon share two pairs of electrons, so the bond is a double bond. Remember, this bond is also covalent! -- If two atoms share one pair of electrons, the bond is a single bond. If two atoms share three pairs of electrons, the bond is called a triple bond. A quadruple bond is pretty much unheard of. -- Here's a tough question: In \(\ce{Cl_2}\), is the bond between the two chlorines 'ionic' or covalent? If it is covalent, is the bond 'single' or 'double'?
pchem_nodes.hint: First, find chlorine on the periodic table. How many valence electrons does each chlorine have? Is the bond ionic or covalent? If it is covalent, how many electrons should each chlorine contribute so that they can share and both have full shells?

pchem_nodes.text:
Nice job! -- Now, if A is more electronegative than B...but doesn't pull hard enough to rip an electron off, what happens? -- Will A and B form an ionic or covalent bond? --
  1. ionic
  2. covalent

Good guess!
--
But since A isn't strong enough to pull an electron off B, they have to share. So they actually form a covalent bond.
--
A, however, is still stronger - and so hogs the electrons closer.
--
So is the area around A more 'positive' or 'negative'?

Nice one!
--
A, however, is still stronger - and so hogs the electrons closer.
--
So is the area around A more 'positive' or 'negative'?

Great!
--
Is the area around B more 'positive' or 'negative'?

Nice! -- Since A hogs the electrons closer to itself, the area around B is slightly positive. This kind of bond is called a polar covalent bond. -- So the B of one molecule and the A of another molecule would be kinda attracted - and this is called dipole-dipole interactions. We'll examine this more later on. -- Well, would this happen if A and B were equally strong? Type 'yes' or 'no'.

You're right! Since A and B are equally strong, they will share the electrons in the middle. So neither is slightly positive or slightly negative. -- This is called a nonpolar covalent bond. -- If oxygen is much stronger than carbon, is the C-O bond 'polar covalent' or 'nonpolar covalent'?

Yep. You seem to have a good understanding of bonds now!
--
Type anything to continue.

Percent Composition

Sometimes, we stumble upon this kind of question: -- An unknown compound X is only made of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. It is 40.00% carbon and 53.29% oxygen by mass. What is the empirical formula of X? -- Well, first, what is an empirical formula? -- An empirical formula is the simplest way to write the molecular formula of a compound, with whole number subscripts. For example, suppose we have the molecule \(C_6H_{12}O_6\). The molecular formula is \(\ce{C_6H_{12}O_6}\), but the empirical formula is \(\ce{CH_2O}\). -- Another example is benzene, \(\ce{C_6H_6}\). It has a molecular formula of \(\ce{C_6H_6}\) but an empirical formula of \(\ce{CH}\). -- What is the empirical formula of \(\ce{C_6H_{12}}\)? Use "_" to denote subscript.
pchem_nodes.hint: If I wanted to answer \(\ce{H_2O}\), I would type 'H_2O'

pchem_nodes.text:
That's right!
--
Now, what does it mean if a compound is "40% carbon by mass"?
--
Well, if the molecule has a mass of 120 amu, then it has \(40\% \times 120 = 48\) amu of carbon atoms in it. Since each carbon atom is about 12 amu, the molecule has 4 carbon atoms in it.
--
So what is the mass percent of carbon in \(\ce{C_6H_6}\)? Express your answer as a percentage to the nearest hundreth.
pchem_nodes.hint: What is the total mass of the carbons in the molecule? What is the total mass of the molecule?

pchem_nodes.text:
Great!
--
Now, we can move on to the original problem.
--
I think the simplest way to proceed is to just assume the compound has a molecular mass of \(M\) amu. Then, in terms of \(M\), what is the mass of the carbon atoms in the molecule?
pchem_nodes.hint: What percentage of the mass is carbon atoms?

pchem_nodes.text:
Nice!
--
So (in terms of \(M\)) how many carbons are in the molecule? Don't simplify.
pchem_nodes.hint: The carbon atoms in the molecule have a mass of \(0.4M\) amu, and each has a mass of 12.01 amu.

pchem_nodes.text:
Yep.
--
Now, repeat for oxygen. In terms of \(M\), how many oxygens are in the molecule?
pchem_nodes.hint: Look at what we did with carbon earlier.

pchem_nodes.text:
Wow!
--
Repeat for hydrogen. In terms of \(M\), how many hydrogens are in the molecule?
pchem_nodes.hint: What percentage of the mass is hydrogen atoms? Remember X is only made of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen.

pchem_nodes.text:
Now, we have expressions for the numbers of different types of atoms.
--
But how can we figure out the actual number?
--
We can look at ratios!
--
For example, if there are 0.5M of element A and 0.5M of element B, then there are an equal number of A and B atoms.
--
So, what is the ratio of hydrogen atoms to oxygen atoms in X? Express your answer as a ratio of whole numbers (like 1:1)
pchem_nodes.hint: How many carbon atoms are there (in terms of \(M\))? How many hydrogen atoms are there? What happens when you divide these two numbers? Does \(M\) cancel out?

pchem_nodes.text:
Nice one!
--
What is the ratio of hydrogen atoms to carbon atoms in X?
So what is the empirical formula of X?
pchem_nodes.hint: If the ratio of carbon to hydrogen is 1:2, and the ratio of hydrogen to oxygen is 2:1, what is the ratio of carbon to hydrogen to oxygen?

pchem_nodes.text:
Great!
--
Congratulations, you just finished the first section!
--
On to the next one...where we learn how to blow stuff up :)
--
Type anything to continue.

Section 2: Chemical Reactions

--

Physical vs Chemical Changes

-- Half of building something out of legos is using the right blocks; the other half is figuring out how to put the blocks together. -- That's what we'll be doing next - exploring how atoms and molecules fit together to form everything around us! -- Atoms and molecules combine together to form new stuff in chemical reactions. When new stuff is formed, this is called a chemical change. -- A physical change is one where something changes form, but stays the same. For example, crumpling up a piece of paper is a physical change, because the paper is still...paper. -- Another example of a physical change is freezing water into ice. Although it looks like something new is formed, in reality ice is made of the same molecules as water, except the molecules move around less and form a solid. So this is a physical change, since nothing chemically new is formed. -- Oftentimes, a chemical change will involve a change in energy, which means the substance reacting could change color, emit light/heat, cool down, etc. -- Chemical changes involve the formation of new stuff, which sometimes is a gas - so bubbles appear. Sometimes, if you mix two liquids together, a new solid forms - and that is a chemical change. -- Let's play a game to see if you can identify if a change is 'physical' or 'chemical': -- Burning wood?

Nice!
--
Since burning wood releases both heat and light, it is a chemical change.
--
Folding origami?

Yep.
--
Since the paper is still paper after folding, no new substance is formed, so it is a physical change.
--
Boiling water?

Mhmm.
--
Boiling water looks like something new is formed - steam! But steam is really just the same molecules as in water, so this is a physical change.
--
Your body breathing in oxygen and breathing out carbon dioxide?

Nice one.
--
Since your body turns oxygen into carbon dioxide (which are two different molecules), this is a chemical change.
--
Mixing baking soda and vinegar?
pchem_nodes.hint: Bubbles form!

pchem_nodes.text:
Wow!
--
Since bubbles form when you mix baking soda and vinegar, it is a chemical change.
--
Here's a tricky one: opening up a can of soda.

Even though bubbles form when you open a can of soda, those bubbles are carbon dioxide, which was injected into the drink when it was made. The carbon dioxide is just released from the drink into the air. So, since no new substance is formed, this is physical.
--
That last example just shows that while what I said above are general guidelines, they are by no means rules.
--
What is a rule: chemical change involves the formation of new substances, and physical change does not.
--
Well, seems like you have a pretty good handle on physical vs chemical changes.
--
Now, let's try out some chemical reactions with the virtual lab!
--
